metadata.title: Assessment on the double role of the transition metal salts on the acetalization of furfural: Lewis and Brønsted acid catalysts

ASSESSMENTDOUBLEROLETRANSITIONMETALSALTSACETALIZATIONFURFURALLEWISBRONSTEDACIDCATALYSTS DASILVA M 1 Introduction 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals 2.2 Catalytic runs 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of transition metal catalyst on the furfural acetalization with methyl alcohol 3.2 Effect of ligand on the palladium-catalyzed furfural acetalization with methyl alcohol 3.3 Effect of gaseous phase on the PdCl2-catalyzed furfural acetalization with methyl alcohol 3.4 Effect of iron catalyst on the furfural acetalization with methyl alcohol 3.5 Assessments the pH effect on the metal-catalyzed furfural acetalization with methyl alcohol 3.6 Effect of FeCl3 concentration on the acetalization of furfural with methyl alcohol 3.7 Insights on the mechanism of the furfural acetalization reaction with methyl alcohol in the presence of transition metal salt 3.8 Effect of alcohol nature on the FeCl3-catalyzed furfural acetalization 4 Conclusion Acknowledgements References DWIVEDI 2015 4050 4058 A LANGE 2012 150 166 J SERRANORUIZ 2012 162 168 J GOMES 2018 1115 1122 G BOZELL 2010 539 554 J FILICIOTTO 2018 2 15 L NEMOTO 2012 7295 7301 H MANDAL 2011 2007 2010 J CLIMENT 2002 565 569 M SILVA 2002 625 634 V SILVA 2006 316 331 V RUBIOCABALLERO 2014 233 236 J BUENO 2007 1 6 A TAARNING 2008 75 78 E CASANOVA 2009 109 116 O AMPELLI 2016 56 65 C KROMPIEC 2012 2057 2095 S DASILVA 2016 3197 3207 M CARARI 2014 615 622 D DASILVA 2015 10529 10536 M MENEZES 2013 16709 16713 F DASILVAX2018X40 DASILVAX2018X40X47 DASILVAX2018X40XM DASILVAX2018X40X47XM 2020-10-11T00:00:00.000Z 2020-10-11T00:00:00.000Z http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ © 2018 Elsevier B.V. https://s3.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-us-east/content/egi:10BF9FQSMR2/MAIN/application/pdf/972505fc18997f37a35f770e5537fa9a/am.pdf MCAT 10207 S2468-8231(18)30482-6 10.1016/j.mcat.2018.10.002 Scheme 1 Transition metal salts-catalyzed furfural acetalization with methyl alcohol. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Proposed mechanism of the H+ cations-catalyzed formation of furfural dimethyl acetal from furfural and methyl alcohol [adapted from 12]. Scheme 2 Scheme 3 Proposed mechanism based on literature for transition metal salt-catalyzed acetal synthesis at room temperature where metal cation acts as Lewis acid [21]. Scheme 3 Fig. 1 Kinetic curves of transition metal-catalyzed acetalization of furfural with methyl alcohola. a Reaction conditions: furfural (5 mmol); catalyst concentration (2 mol %); temperature (298 K); methyl alcohol (10 mL). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Effect of anion present on palladium salts in the acetalization reaction of furfural with methyl alcohol at room temperaturea. aReaction conditions: furfural (5 mmol); catalyst concentration (2 mol %); temperature (298 K); methyl alcohol (10 mL); reaction time (2 h). bThe initial pH of methyl alcohol was 6.2. cThe measurements of pH were done only in the presence of alcohol and catalyst. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Effect of gaseous phase on PdCl2-catalyzed furfural acetalization with methyl alcohol under different gaseous phase at room temperature in the absence of reoxidanta,b. aReaction conditions: furfural (5 mmol); PdCl2 catalyst concentration (2 mol %); gas phase (1 atm); temperature (298 K); methyl alcohol (10 mL); reaction time (2 h). bUnder nitrogen, Pd(0) species were formed after 30 min of reaction. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Effect of catalyst load on PdCl2-catalyzed furfural acetalization with methyl alcohola. aReaction conditions: furfural (5 mmol); temperature (298 K); methyl alcohol (10 mL); reaction time (2 h). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Kinetic curves of iron salts-catalyzed acetalization of furfural with methyl alcohola. aReaction conditions: furfural (5 mmol); catalyst concentration (0.05 mol %); temperature (298 K); methyl alcohol (10 mL). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Effect of FeCl3 concentration on conversion of furfural to furfural dimethyl acetala. a Reaction conditions: furfural (5 mmol); temperature (298 K); methanol (10 mL). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Furfural conversion obtained with different FeCl3 catalyst load and the pH values measured. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Effect of alcohol nature on the FeCl3-catalyzed furfural acetalization at room temperaturea. aReaction conditions: furfural (5 mmol); FeCl3·6H2O concentration (0.05 mol%); temperature (298 K); methanol (10 mL). Fig. 8 Table 1 Effect of transition metal catalyst on acetalization of furfural with methyl alcohol at room temperature. a Table 1 Run Catalyst Conversion b (%) pH value c SelectivityFurfural dimethyl acetal(%) 1 – 5 6.2 92 2 FeCl3·6 H2O 94 1.7 97 3 PdCl2 92 2.8 98 4 CoCl2·6 H2O 23 5.8 98 5 CuCl2·3 H2O 70 3.1 97 6 NiCl2·6 H2O 81 5.4 97 7 LiCl 15 6.2 56 a Reaction conditions: furfural (5 mmol); catalyst concentration (2 mol %); temperature (298 K); methyl alcohol (10 mL); reaction time (2 h). b Conversion and selectivity were calculated via GC analysis of pattern curves built with pure compounds (i.e., furfural and furfural dimethyl acetal (i.e., 2-(dimethoxymethyl)furan)). c The measurements of pH were done only in the presence of alcohol and catalyst. Assessment on the double role of the transition metal salts on the acetalization of furfural: Lewis and Brønsted acid catalysts Márcio José da Silva ⁎ Milena Galdino Teixeira Chemistry Department, Federal University of Viçosa, Viçosa, Minas Gerais, 36590-000, Brazil Chemistry Department Federal University of Viçosa Viçosa Minas Gerais 36590-000 Brazil ⁎ Corresponding author at: Chemistry Department, Federal University of Viçosa, Campus Universitário, Avenue P.H. Rolfs, s/n, Viçosa, Minas Gerais State, CEP: 36570-000, Brazil. Chemistry Department Federal University of Viçosa Campus Universitário Avenue P.H. Rolfs, s/n Viçosa Minas Gerais State CEP: 36570-000 Brazil Graphical abstract The conversion of biomass derived to more valuable compounds has attracted growing attention due to the economic and environmental reasons. In special, the furfural deserves highlight because it is a versatile biorefinery platform-molecule and has been used as feedstock to produce fuels and fine chemicals. In this work, we have developed a process to synthesize furfural acetals at room temperature in transition metal-catalyzed reactions using different alcohols. Among the transition metal catalysts, the FeCl3 provided the highest catalytic activity (ca. 90% conversion within 1 h reaction) and highest furfural acetal yield (ca. 94% of 2-(dimethoxymethyl)furan). Effects of main reaction parameters such as e.g. reaction time, catalyst concentration and pH of medium were assessed. Based on experimental results, we conclude that metal salts (i.e., mainly FeCl3 and NiCl2) act as Lewis and Brønsted acid catalysts on these reactions. The reaction scope was successfully extended to the different alcohols. A special attention was paid to assess the effects of catalyst nature on these processes. Keywords Furfural Transition metal salt catalysts Acetalization Biomass 1 Introduction Biomass derived compounds have been used in the production of biofuels and value-added chemicals aiming to minimize the dependence on fossil reserves [1]. On this sense, the furfural produced through dehydration of xylan contained in lignocellulose deserves highlight, because it has been used as platform-molecule in a plethora of chemical transformations [2,3]. Currently, furfural has been upgraded to a variety of chemicals or biofuel components [4,5]. Nevertheless, to make the furfural an able compound to be blended to the hydrocarbon fuels, the polarity of its aldehyde group and its volatility should be lowered, normally, trough the functionalization processes such as the hydrogenation or alkylation reactions [6]. Several approaches have been done such as combine the furfural hydrogenation with acid-catalyzed rearrangement or etherification reactions [7]. Alternatively, acetalization reactions which are viable routes to protect carbonyl functionalities in the organic compounds are also an attractive synthetic strategy to synthesize furfural derivatives [8]. In general, acetalization reactions have been carried out in the presence of liquid Brønsted acid catalysts, however, these homogeneous processes have serious drawbacks. The large generation of effluents and residues during the steps of products purification and acid catalyst neutralization makes these processes unfriendly environment. In addition, the high corrosiveness besides the impossibility to reuse the catalyst hamper the use of homogeneous Bronsted acids in an industrial scale [9]. When the acetalization reactions are carried out in presence of Brønsted acid catalysts, the formed acetal can be easily hydrolyzed, regenerating then the furfural. To prevent it, a large excess of ethyl alcohol has been used (ca. 100: 1) aiming to shift the equilibrium toward products [9]. Despite the large excess, the alcohol can be recovered by distillation and reused in another reaction. Solid acid catalysts have been used as an alternative in processes of furfural condensation with alcohols to produce acetals [10,11]. Riisager et al. described the use of commercial zeolites (i.e., HUSY zeolite) as catalysts in the acetalization of furfural to produce furfural diethyl acetal, using ethyl alcohol as a renewable solvent [12]. Another different approach was adopted by Gusevskaya et al., which developed a selective synthesis route of acetals based on Pd(II)-catalyzed oxidation reactions of primary alcohols [13]. Another route to convert furfural to a product that can be blended to the gasoline or diesel is promote its oxidation to carboxylic acid and afterward, esterified it with an alcohol [14,15]. Perathoner et al. performed the oxidative esterification of furfural over Au/ ZrO2 catalysts achieving an almost complete conversion and 95% of selectivity to 2-methyl furoate [16]. However, very drastic reaction conditions were required for these reactions (ca. 3.0 bar of oxygen pressure and 393 K temperature). In this work, we decide to investigate the activity of transition metal catalysts in furfural acetalization reactions carried out in different alcohols. Under these conditions, a novel route to convert furfural to dialkyl acetal was developed, via transition metal-catalyzed reactions under mild conditions (i.e., temperature and pressure environment). We explored the ability of metal catalysts react with alcohol releasing H+ cations, which in solution act the catalyst. The reaction scope was successfully extended to the different alcohols. An attention special was paid to the study the effect of main variables of reaction, such as the nature and the concentration of catalyst. Based on experimental results, a mechanistic proposal was performed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals All chemicals are commercially available and utilized without prior handling. LiCl (99 wt. %) was acquired from Merck. CoCl2·6 H2O (98 wt. %), CuCl2·4 H2O (99 wt. %), NiCl2·6 H2O (97 wt. %), FeCl3·6 H2O (97 wt. %) and Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O (98 wt. %) were purchased from Vetec. Fe(SO4)·7 H2O (99 wt. %), Fe2(SO4)3 (97 wt. %), palladium salts (i.e., PdCl2, Pd(CH3COO)2, Pd(CF3COO)2 and Pd(acac)2; 99 wt. %), and KHCO3 (97 wt. %) were acquired from Sigma-Aldrich. Furfural (ca. 99 wt. %) and all the solvents (methyl, ethyl, n-propyl, isopropyl, and n-butyl alcohols; > 99.5 wt. %) were also acquired from Sigma Aldrich. 2.2 Catalytic runs Catalytic runs were performed in a glass reactor (ca. 50 mL) equipped with a magnetic stirrer and sampling septum. Typically, the transition metal catalyst (ca. 2 mol %) was dissolved in alcohol (ca. 10 mL solution); then the furfural (ca. 5 mmol) was added to the solution and the reaction was initiated. The reaction progress was monitored by GC analyses of aliquots taken at regular time intervals in a Shimadzu GC 2010 instrument, FID, fitted with Carbowax 20 M capillary column. Dodecane was the internal standard. The comparison of the corresponding GC peak areas of products and substrate with the corresponding calibrating curves provided the reaction conversion. Eqs. (1) and (2) allowed to calculate the conversion and products selectivity of the reactions. (1) f u r f u r a l c o n v e r s i o n % = ( C i - C f ) C i x 100 Where Ci = initial concentration of furfural; Cf = final concentration of furfural (2) S e l e c t i v i t y % = A p A F i - A F f x 100 Where Ap = GC peak area of acetal; AFi = GC peak initial area of furfural; AFf = GC peak final area of furfural The main reaction products were identified by GC/MS analyses (Shimadzu MS-QP 2014 ultra mass spectrometer instrument) operating at 70 eV, coupled with a Shimadzu 2014 GC. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of transition metal catalyst on the furfural acetalization with methyl alcohol Literature has described the use of transition metal complexes in the synthesis of acetals and orthoesters [17]. However, as far we know, commercial metal salts have been scarcely used in these processes. Our first intention was to verify what among the transition metal salts may efficiently catalyze the acetalization reaction of the furfural with methyl alcohol. The kinetic curves are displayed in Fig. 1 . In a previous work, we have found that transition metal salt catalysts have the ability to promote esterification reactions of terpenic alcohols directly releasing H+ cations through reactions with the HOAc solvent [18]. Although the HOAc to be a weak acid, in the presence of metal salts its ionization was enhanced and a high H+ cations concentration was achieved. Therefore, aiming to verify if this reaction also occurred herein we measured the pH of the solutions in the absence and presence of different metal catalysts (Table 1 ). It is important highlight that the pH measurements carried out herein are related to the H+ cation released in solution; it is not important if it is coordinated to the solvent (i.e., CH3OH2 +) or any residual water (i.e., H3O+). This measurement is enough for us to have a reference of medium acidity in all the reactions. Moreover, the pH was measured at the reaction beginning (i.e., only with alcohol and catalyst, footnote “c”, Table 1)). Although an excess of methyl alcohol has been used (1: 50), in the absence of catalyst only a poor conversion of furfural to furfural dimethyl acetal happened (ca. 5%, entry 1, Table 1). In the presence of transition metal salt catalysts, the furfural was selectively converted to furfural dimethyl acetal (Scheme 1 ), the only GC peak of product detected in the reaction. Despite the furfural acetalization to be a reversible reaction that results in water as co-product (Scheme 1), the presence or absence of hydration water molecules in the metal salt had not any effect on the activity of the catalysts. Conversely, an analysis of pH values shown in Table 1 suggests that the activity of metal catalysts was straightly linked to its ability to react with methyl alcohol releasing H+ cations (Eq. (1)). Although the metal alkoxides have been frequently obtained in reactions between alkaline metal hydroxide and alcohols, we have found that in the conditions studied herein the alkoxylation reaction also takes place. Indeed, previously we had observed the same reaction when assessed the transition metal-catalyzed alkoxylation of olefins with alcohols [20]. It was found that in practically all catalytic runs where occurred a higher lowering of the pH value, the condensation reaction provided a higher conversion of furfural to dimethyl acetal. The two highest conversions (ca. 94 and 92%, entries 2 and 3, Table 1) were achieved in the reaction where the pH values were the lowest (i.e., 1.7 and 2.8), in the presence of FeCl3 and PdCl2 catalysts, respectively. The experimental data collected after the reaction end showed that the pH remained almost unaltered in all runs. Conversely, the NiCl2 or CuCl2-catalyzed reactions had a different behavior; apparently, there was no correlation between the pH value and the conversions achieved in the reactions (i.e., 62 and 81% of conversion were obtained in reactions with pH values of 3.2 and 5.4). It is suggestive that Lewis acidity of NiCl2 catalyst plays also an important role on these processes. We suppose the Ni2+ metal cation can act as a Lewis acid, polarizing the carbonyl group of furfural, and favoring its attack by the hydroxyl group of the alcohol. 3.2 Effect of ligand on the palladium-catalyzed furfural acetalization with methyl alcohol The stability of acid formed by the H+ cation and the anion present in the metal salt was another crucial aspect that affected the efficiency of the catalysts. To check this effect, we carried out some experiments with palladium salts containing different anions. The main results are presented in Fig. 2 . It is noteworthy that due to the high price, palladium salts are not the better choice for these reactions; however, our objective herein was only to assess if the anion present in the metal salt could or not to affect the reaction. We previously demonstrated that the addition of a metal salt to the alcohol solution can give an alkoxide-metal and a Brønsted acid, this late able to catalyze the furfural acetalization (see Scheme 2 ) [19,20]. Therefore, it is reasonable hope that the palladium salts will proceed similarly and has its activity affected by the anion. In addition, this ligand anion may be also strongly or weakly coordinated to the palladium, another aspect that will has influence on the reaction. Herein, we have found that the palladium catalysts containing an anion that will result in a strong acid (i.e., PdCl2 and Pd(CF3COO)2 give HCl and CF3COOH, respectively), were the most active. This observation can be attributed to the high dissociation of strong acid formed. Conversely, when the anion present in the palladium salt will resulted in a weak acid (i.e., Pd(CH3COO)2 give CH3COOH), the catalyst palladium was less active (ca. 62% conversion, Fig. 2). When a ligand as acetylacetonate is coordinate to the Pd(II), no typical Brønsted acid is formed; consequently, Pd(acac)2 catalyst was almost inactive (ca. 6% conversion, Fig. 2). There is another important aspect to be considered aiming to explain the activity of palladium catalysts; the strength of ligand on palladium. It could be expected that a strong ligand with low lability could hamper the reactions; for instance, this fact could be explaining why the acetylacetonate palladium-catalyzed reactions reached only ca. 12% of conversion (Fig. 2). However, when the ligand on palladium was the trifluoroacetate, which is the strongest ligand herein, a high conversion was achieved (ca. 86%, Fig. 2). The main difference between these two cases is that although the two anions are strong ligands, after the reaction of Pd(CF3COO)2 with CH3OH, the proton generated remains dissociated because the conjugated acid is a strong acid (i.e., CF3COOH); the opposite occurs with o acetylacetonate ligand, which after to react with the methanol generates only acetylacetone (i.e., neutral molecule). The pH value measurements are an evidence that these hypotheses are true. Therefore, the low activity of Pd(acac)2 can be attributed to these two aspects; the strength ligand and the conjugate specie formed after the reaction with the alcohol. 3.3 Effect of gaseous phase on the PdCl2-catalyzed furfural acetalization with methyl alcohol It is important to highlight that the literature has described the use of palladium catalysts in reactions to synthesize acetals directly from alcohols, but without the presence of aldehydes [13]. These palladium-catalyzed reactions occur through the oxidative process under oxygen atmosphere in Pd(OH)2/ Cu(OAc)2/ p-TSA catalyst system. To check if any an oxidative pathway could be also operating herein, we performed the reactions under different atmospheres (Fig. 3 ). In the absence of oxidant atmosphere, the reaction seems proceed less favorably and the furfural conversion was lower (ca. 78%, Fig. 3), notwithstanding the furfural dimethyl acetal selectivity has been kept as high as 84%. Expectedly, under nitrogen atmosphere and without a reoxidant, the palladium-black species were formed at beginning reaction (footnote “b”, Fig. 3), probably, due to the stoichiometric oxidation of methyl alcohol to formaldehyde by the Pd(II) salt [13]. The deactivation of palladium catalyst via methyl alcohol stoichiometric oxidation can explain because the conversion of furfural acetalization was lower under nitrogen atmosphere. Nevertheless, we can conclude that deactivation is slower than acetalization, because a furfural conversion of 78% was achieved before the Pd(0) has been significantly formed. On the other hand, we can discard an oxidative route of acetalization, because the furfural acetalization was very higher than Pd(II): furfural stochiometric reason; 78% conversion was achieved with PdCl2 (2 mol %). It is suggestive that PdCl2 participate of the reaction, probably, generating H+ cations, which resulted in the reduction of pH value (i.e., 6.2–2.8, Table 1). An important question is what is the minimum load of palladium chloride that is still able to catalyze the process. In Figure 4 $ the main results are presented. We have found that palladium chloride is active even at low concentration (Fig. 4 ). It can explain why even after the beginning of the formation of palladium-black reduced species under nitrogen gas, the reaction achieved 78% of conversion; as we started the reaction with an initial concentration of PdCl2 equal to 2.0 mol % (Fig. 3), the non-reduced palladium was enough for that the reaction to reach this conversion. 3.4 Effect of iron catalyst on the furfural acetalization with methyl alcohol As previously demonstrated, the anion may have a strong effect on the catalytic efficiency of metal salt. In addition, the metal oxidation state may be also having an important role for the successful of catalyst. Therefore, we carried out reactions in the presence of different iron salts (Fig. 5 ). When we compared the performance of the different iron catalysts at lower conversion and as a function of the reaction time we concluded that the FeCl3 or Fe(NO3)3-catalyzed reactions achieved the maximum conversion within the first fifteen reaction minutes (Fig. 5). Although the Fe2(SO4)3 catalyst also has been efficient and virtually converted all the furfural to acetal, the reaction was slower than two first mentioned. The only Fe(II) catalyst tested was the less efficient than the Fe(III) salts. Table 2 shows the results of selectivity and pH values obtained with different iron salts on furfural acetalization with methyl alcohol. The anion on metal cation looks have an important effect on these reactions, mainly in relation to the pH of the reaction, and consequently, in the conversion. The higher pH values were obtained in the reaction where the anion sulfate was present. Likewise observed when we evaluated the anion effect on the palladium (Section 3.2), when the proton produced by the reaction of the metal cation and the alcohol can to react with an anion and generate a weak acid (i.e., in this case, HSO4 −anion), the pH of the reaction stays between 5.0–5.7 (Table 2). Conversely, nitrate and chloride anions resulted in lower pH values, because strong acid are formed. On the other hand, the pH looks to play a key role only in some of these reactions; for instance, the FeCl3 or Fe(NO3)3-catalyzed reactions carried out at low pH values had reached high conversions (i.e., 91 and 90%, runs 1 and 2, pH 2.3 and 2.2, respectively, Table 2). Conversely, it was not true for the other two reaction; the Fe2(SO4)3 or FeSO4-catalyzed reactions achieved high conversions (ca. 89 and 83%, even being the pH equal to 5. 7 and 5.0, respectively (Table 2). The same was observed in the NiCl2-catalyzed reaction, which reached ca. 81% of conversion with a pH of 5.4 after the addition of catalyst (Table 1). Notwithstanding, the different pH values, the Fe3+-catalyzed reactions reached higher conversions. We concluded that it suggests that the pH it is not always the only issue that governs these reactions; probably, the Lewis acidity of metal cation may be also an important aspect for these reactions. Therefore, aiming check “if” or “when” the pH is truly related with the efficiency of the transition metal salt catalyst on the furfural acetalization reactions, or if the Lewis acidity of metal cation also plays key role on these processes, on the next section we performed some reactions in the presence of a true Brønsted acid (p-toluenesulfonic acid), in the presence of an acid scavenger (i.e., KHCO3) or only with the metal catalyst alone. 3.5 Assessments the pH effect on the metal-catalyzed furfural acetalization with methyl alcohol To assure that this reaction is being catalyzed by H+ cations generated “in situ” by the reaction between metal catalyst and methyl alcohol, we carried out reactions presented in Table 3 . The first one, without a metal catalyst but with a true Brønsted acid (i.e., p-toluenesulfonic acid, p-TSA; entry 1, Table 3). The other reactions, with a metal catalyst (i.e., FeCl3 or NiCl2) in the presence or absence of an acid scavenger (i.e., KHCO3). Expectedly, in the presence of true Brønsted acid (i.e. p-TSA, entry 1, Table 3), the reaction achieved a high conversion, although lower than that reached in metal-catalyzed reactions (entries 3 and 5, Table 3). Conversely, all the runs carried out in the presence of an acid scavenger attained only a poor conversion, regardless presence of Lewis or Brønsted acid catalyst. It is an evidence that H+ cations are the true catalyst on these reactions; when the H+ cations generated by the metal salts are neutralized by the presence of a Brønsted base, the acetalization reaction is hampered. No furfural conversion was detected. The lowest pH value was achieved when p-toluenesulfonic acid was the catalyst; nonetheless, it was not the best catalyst, the conversion was lower than several transition metal salt-catalyzed reactions (see Tables 1–3). Therefore, even though the results on Table 3 clearly shows that the reactions do not proceed under alkaline conditions, they also demonstrated that the Bronsted acidity it is not the only driving force that can control these reactions. In addition to be cheaper than PdCl2, another very active catalyst on these reactions, the FeCl3 was the most active and selective; therefore, it was selected to study the effect of main reaction parameters on the following sections. 3.6 Effect of FeCl3 concentration on the acetalization of furfural with methyl alcohol The catalyst concentration should not affect the equilibrium conversion of a reaction; however, our reactions were carried within a time interval determined, regardless the equilibrium has been or not achieved. Therefore, when we varied the catalyst load the reaction conversions were changed (Fig. 6 ). An increasing on catalyst concentration enhanced the rate of furfural conversion (Fig. 5a and b). Reducing the catalyst load until 5 × 10−3 mol % has no prejudicial effect to conversion final; all the reaction reached conversions ranging of 90–94 % within first 2 h of reaction. Only for concentrations lower than 5 10−3 mol % was observed a reduction of the final conversion. Consequently, the FeCl3 catalyst achieved high turnover number (TON) (Table 4 ). Moreover, we have found that the furfural acetal selectivity in all the reactions stayed higher than 90% throughout the whole process, regardless the concentration used (Table 4). The Fig. 7 shows clearly the relation between FeCl3 catalyst concentration, the pH solution and the conversions achieved after 2 h of reaction. A lower load of FeCl3 catalyst resulted in a minor generation of H+ cations, consequently, the pH values were more elevated, and the furfural conversion was also reduced. Furthermore, in the presence of an acid scavenger, the furfural was not converted to acetal. 3.7 Insights on the mechanism of the furfural acetalization reaction with methyl alcohol in the presence of transition metal salt Based on experimental results and literature data [18], a plausible mechanistic proposal involving the H+ cations generated in the reaction of metal salt and alcohol methyl was suggested and is depicted in the Scheme 2 [12]. Looks reasonable assumes that the reaction involves two distinct steps: in the first, the Lewis acid catalyst (i.e., transition metal salt) react with alcohol giving a metal-alkoxide intermediate and HX (Eq. (1)); the second step involves only a Brønsted acid catalyst, which will promote the reaction of furfural with methyl alcohol through several stages (Scheme 2) [12]. Indeed, the main role of transition metal salt catalyst is to generate H+ cations, which seem to be the true catalyst for acetalization process. After has been generated, the H+ cation protonates the furfural carbonyl group (step 1, Scheme 2), generating an sp2 -intermediate that can be more favorably attacked by methyl alcohol (step 2, Scheme 2). This tetrahedral intermediate undergoes a prototropism reaction (step 3, Scheme 2), which result in the releasing of the water molecule (step 4, Scheme 2). The oxonium ion resulting is then attacked by another alcohol molecule ((step 5, Scheme 2), giving the protonate acetal; this last specie release H+ cation (step 6, Scheme 2), that can thus start another catalytic cycle. A closer look on the results of Tables 1–3, and Fig. 7, reveals that some transition metal salts were active even though without a significant lowering the pH value. Although the activity of FeCl3 looks has been affected by increasing of pH (i.e., the conversion dropped of 90 to 53% with the pH value raised of 2.3–4.7, Fig. 7), the reactions in the presence of NiCl2 (Table 1) or Fe2(SO4)3 (Table 3) achieved conversions of 81 and 89%, with pH values of 5.4 and 5.7, respectively. Thus, seems reasonable suppose that the Bronsted acidity generated by the metal cations it is not the only aspect to be considered to explain the action of the catalyst. We think that Lewis acidity of transition metal salts, which is linked to ability in accept electrons on the d-orbitals, can also be important for these reactions. In general, the Lewis or acid Brønsted acid catalysts act in acetalization reactions activating the aldehyde carbonyl group, trough of protonation step (i.e., Brønsted acids, Scheme 2) or polarization after coordination step (i.e., Lewis acid, Scheme 3 ). Both processes can favor the nucleophilic attack by hydroxyl group of alcohol, resulting in the formation in solution of a metal-coordinated intermediate, which after successive steps will give acetal. Therefore, regardless the H+ cations concentration the generated by the transition metal salt catalyst (Scheme 2), it can participate in the initial step of reaction activating the oxygen atom of the furfural carbonyl group. Consequently, the nucleophilic attack of alcohol hydroxyl group on the carbonylic carbon can be favored and the reaction can proceed to give acetal. We have found that the most active Lewis acid catalyst was the FeCl3, followed by the PdCl2 and NiCl2 salts. The activation of furfural by the metal cation involves an interaction between the “π”-orbital electrons of furfural carbonylic oxygen atom (i.e., donating HOMO orbital) and the “d”-orbital of metal (acceptor LUMO orbital). This is a typical Lewis acid/base interaction. Notwithstanding, this interaction can be also explained in terms of HASB theory, because the Fe3+ ion is harder acid than the other cations, while the oxygen atom is also hard base. Although the presence of the alcohol molecules in large concentration may have difficulted the interaction metal cation-furfural, the results showed that probably, due to the weakness of alcohol as ligand, it was not enough to hamper the acetalization reaction. It is important to highlight that the addition of a Bronsted base (i.e., HCO3 −) hampered that the acetalization reaction could proceed normally, even in the presence of NiCl2 catalyst (run 6, Table 3). It can be attributed to the competition by the acid Lewis acid site (i.e., Ni2+) between the base (i.e., HCO3 − is a bidentate ligand) and the furfural carbonyl group. Since the HCO3 − anion is a ligand stronger than furfural, it will coordinate to the Ni2+ cation, avoiding the activation of substrate. 3.8 Effect of alcohol nature on the FeCl3-catalyzed furfural acetalization It is expected that an increasing on alcohol carbon chain size or a change of chemical environment surround the carbonyl group may affect the reactivity of alcohol, and consequently, to change the furfural conversion to acetal. Therefore, the reaction scope was extended to the other alcohols and the results are summarized in Table 5 . Although alcohol excess, in the absence of catalyst only a poor conversion of furfural was achieved (run 1–5, ca. ≤5%, Table 5), regardless the alcohol. Moreover, as except to the sec-propyl alcohol, acetal was always the major product. Conversely, when the catalyst was present, the reactions achieved conversions between 52 and 91%. In general, an increasing on carbon chain size of alcohol resulted in decreasing on furfural conversion (runs 6–10, Table 5). Due to the high steric hindrance on hydroxyl group, only a poor conversion was achieved when the isopropyl alcohol was the substrate, even in catalyzed-reactions. The reactivity alcohol was as follow CH3OH > C2H5OH > C3H7OH > C4H9OH > sec-C3H5OH. Regardless the alcohol substrate, all the reactions achieved the maximum conversion within short reaction time (Fig. 8 ). Differently of observed in previous sections, the conversion of the reactions was not affected by pH of medium. Although the sec-propyl alcohol has presented the lowest pH value, it was the less reactive alcohol. 4 Conclusion In this work, we have investigated the ability of transition metal salts to catalyze furfural acetalization reaction with different alcohols at room temperature. Among the metal catalysts, the FeCl3 provided the highest activity, reaching conversions and acetal selectivity of ca. 90% even when used at very low concentration (ca. 5 × 10−3 mol %). The high TON values show that this is a highly efficient process to synthesize furfural acetals. Regardless the alcohol used, furfural acetal was always the main product. In these processes, we have found that the H+ cations are generated by the reaction between transition metal catalysts and alcohol. Experiments with Bronsted acid scavenger supported this proposal. However, depends on the transition metal catalyst, it is also possible that another mechanism also has operated. Notwithstanding the H+ cations concentration that the metal cation can produce, itself can participate of the initial step of reaction as a true Lewis acid, activating the oxygen atom of the furfural carbonyl group. The reaction scope was extended to the other alcohols and we can found that both size of carbon chain and steric hindrance on hydroxyl group affect the reaction conversion. A special attention was dedicated to assessing the role of palladium catalysts on these reactions. We demonstrated that at the experimental conditions used herein, no oxidative mechanism involving palladium was observed. The use of non-corrosive, simple and inexpensive commercial catalyst are positive aspects of this acetal synthesis procedure. coredata.dc:description: The conversion of biomass derived to more valuable compounds has attracted growing attention due to the economic and environmental reasons. In special, the furfural deserves highlight because it is a versatile biorefinery platform-molecule and has been used as feedstock to produce fuels and fine chemicals. In this work, we have developed a process to synthesize furfural acetals at room temperature in transition metal-catalyzed reactions using different alcohols. Among the transition metal catalysts, the FeCl3 provided the highest catalytic activity (ca. 90% conversion within 1 h reaction) and highest furfural acetal yield (ca. 94% of 2-(dimethoxymethyl)furan). Effects of main reaction parameters such as e.g. reaction time, catalyst concentration and pH of medium were assessed. Based on experimental results, we conclude that metal salts (i.e., mainly FeCl3 and NiCl2) act as Lewis and Brønsted acid catalysts on these reactions. The reaction scope was successfully extended to the different alcohols. A special attention was paid to assess the effects of catalyst nature on these processes.
coredata.dc:title: Assessment on the double role of the transition metal salts on the acetalization of furfural: Lewis and Brønsted acid catalysts
